content.description: There is a really good selection of boulder routes I cleaned a couple hundred feet up the trail to Bear Cub cliff providing a great warm up to the early morning.
content.location: Boulders on the left side of trail just as it begins to get steep

climbs.name: Dolomite Duet
climbs.fa: Paul Cormier on left, Joe Cormier on right

content.description: Begin the two pitch climb at a cave and move right onto the face making moves on horizontal cracks until you can place gear in the hand cracks moving up to the anchors about 40 feet the next pitch begins on a flake to the first of five bolts If you climb the left side of the bolts it is much harder at 5.10 if you climb the right side the grade stays 5.7 above you can use a variety of gear and bolts to reach the anchor on a ledge
content.protection: Traditional rack up to hand size cams

content.description: 30 feet down from the Bear Den start is a big wall to a big over lap look for bolts.  make hard face moves protecting a finger jam into the overlap to (3)bolts and step left around the overlap onto the face above.  follow the crack system trending up and right to the mid anchor station above Bear Season.  or escape left to anchors for Dolomite Duet.

Start at the base of a large oak move up a slab to gain a good crack some grass grows on a ledge but it is not wet move into the crack and follow the large fist jam to the overlap.  The thin crack above Takes you to another overlap and into a deep jam you must make the overlap with a high left foot 5.8 and two crimps on a slab to reach the mid station anchor the next pitch stays in the corner to the right and protection is placed in the crack  eventually veer toward the large pine tree in the middle of the cliff you can belay from the tree and use the rappel anchor for dolomite duet nearby
content.protection: Tradition rack up to  hand size cams

content.description: The beginning of the climb you’ll see a pine tree about 20 feet up the initial 20 feet will be a scramble using passive protection on the slab aiming for a under cling Once reaching the under clean you will be able to back up #.75 with a #.2 moving out left with your feet high under cling the ramp and reach out with your left hand to a good hold  you can place a #1 cam move up the crack system you can place #.1 cam before making a delicate move to another roof  at the small roof clip a bolt and figure out the Boulder move 5.10B then clip the next bolt and make a heady finish to the slings at a bonsai tree
content.protection: trad hand sized cams and draws
content.location: Look for the bonsai red pine at the top and another pine on the left mid way up the route

content.description: Start at the cave and move onto the arete.  run it out to the two bolt rap anchor.  Further continue up to a wall on the right.  put in a backed up cam or two at the base of the wall and send directly to easier terrain.  not for the faint of heart but good
content.protection: trad rack up to hand sizes

content.description: This cliff has its own parking and trail.  Drive to Tumbledown Dick Gilead as for rock climbing look for a grass road cliff side and follow it.   Park at the fire ring.  Walk the grassy rd to a small stream and follow the numerous cairns and flagging tape straight up the hill side passing some good boulders and vistas along the way to the reach the base of the climbs.
